title: Ticket #309: HAD replication daemon can only replicate a single file
description:
Currently, the HAD replication daemon is hard-coded to replicate a single file. For hadoop, it may be necessary for it to handle a list of files.

Timeline:

  1. Complete: 8 Jan 2010
remarks:
2009-May-28 11:58:47 by nleroy:
I was led to believe that this would be a pretty simple update -- I think that there were some communications problems that led me to that belief.

This will going to be a bigger job than I had previously anticipated. :(

2009-Nov-18 10:45:29 by nleroy:

Replicating HDFS state files

  1. HDFS can produce files that reflect it's current state
    1. 1 file is the state at the most recent rebuild
    2. 1 file is a append-only log file; this file can grow quite large

  2. Current proposal
    1. Replicator would handle a set of files
      1. Track version of the entire set, not individual files
      2. Largest mtime of all of the files would be used as the mtime of the entire set
    2. Give the replicator the ability to track the size of a file, and to push additions to append-only files

  3. Problems
    1. This model doesn't handle multiple peers. Consider the following:
      • Define peers: A, B, C; A is the master
      • Define files: "state", "log"; "log" is append-only
      • A initially pushes "state" and "log" to B and C
      • A pushes additions to "log" to B and C (zero or more times)
      • Peer C goes down
      • A pushes additions to "log" to B, but not C (one or more times)
      • Peer C comes back up
      • A pushes additions to "log" to B and C
        • "log" on C is now corrupt -- it does not contain the additions pushed while C was down

2009-Nov-18 11:08:20 by nleroy:

Replicating HDFS state files solution

  1. Replicator daemon reverts back to similar to that of 7.4.x, but:
    • Knows of file sets
    • File set mtime defined by the most recent mtime
    • File name + ctime included in decision of when to move file set, from which machine, etc.
    • Communicate with other replicator(s) by sending ClassAds

  2. Transferer daemon gains a lot of intelligence:
    • Knows about the list of files to replicate, which are append-only, etc.
    • Communicate with each other via ClassAds

  3. Transferer Protocol:
    1. Sender sends complete state via ClassAd
    2. For each file that that requires transfer:
      1. Receiver sends "send file request" via ClassAd
        • file path (relative to base)
        • beginning offset to send (0 == entire file)
      2. Sender sends "pushing file" command via ClassAd or NAK
        • file path (should match request)
        • file meta data (currently: ctime)
        • beginning offset (should match request)
        • number of bytes to send
      3. Data transfer
      4. After transfer complete, receiver sets file meta data to match sender's

2010-Oct-06 23:44:42 by ilikhan:
With the new version of Hadoop (0.21.0) we do not need HAD replication daemon to replicate HDFS state files. We can configure a machine to be Backup Node to maintain an in-memory up-to-date copy of the file system namespace that is always synchronized with the active NameNode state. See http://hadoop.apache.org/hdfs/docs/r0.21.0/hdfs_user_guide.html#Secondary+NameNode

So, should we cancel this task?
